nodes.text: Settler mortality during European colonization affected the type of institutions established, and those institutions have large causal effects on current income per capita
European colonizers adopted different colonization strategies that produced different institutional arrangements (extractive states versus settler-based Neo-Europes)
The feasibility of European settlement was strongly influenced by the disease environment and settler mortality
Early colonial institutions persisted after independence and shaped modern institutions
Identification strategy: use historical settler mortality as an instrument for current institutions to estimate institutions' causal effect on income
Data on settler mortality are drawn from historical sources (soldiers, bishops, sailors, Curtin and others) to proxy mortality faced by potential settlers
Institutions are proxied mainly by average protection against expropriation risk (Political Risk Services) and by early constraint/democracy indices (Polity)
Historical evidence and examples (e.g., Sierra Leone, Pilgrims, Australia, Belgian Congo, Latin America) show settlements, mortality, and differing colonial institutions
Empirical evidence: higher historical settler mortality correlates with fewer settlements and worse early institutions; settlements correlate with early institutions
First-stage regression: log settler mortality explains a large share (e.g., ~25–30%) of cross-country variation in current institutions

Two-stage least-squares estimates: instrumenting institutions with settler mortality yields a large, statistically significant effect of institutions on log income per capita (2SLS coefficients ~0.9–1.3)

Robustness checks: results persist when controlling for latitude, colonial origin, legal origin, religion, climate, natural resources, soil quality, ethnolinguistic fragmentation, current disease measures, and excluding outliers (Neo-Europes, Africa)

Overidentification and specification tests: using additional instruments (settlements, early institutions, yellow fever dummy) yields no evidence of a direct effect of settler mortality on current income beyond its effect through institutions

Conclusion: Institutional differences originating in colonial experience are major determinants of present income differences; geographic proxies (latitude, Africa dummy) lose significance once institutions are instrumented
Limitation: Institutions are treated as a 'black box' (cluster of institutional features); the analysis does not prescribe concrete policy steps to change underlying institutional equilibria
Context: Existing literature documents correlations between institutions and development and discusses colonial origins, diseases, and legal/cultural channels
